snippet: The carbon emissions standards, proposed last year for the nation’s coal-fired power plants, could prevent more than 3,000 premature deaths per year, according to a new study.
abstract: Study published in journal Nature Climate Change finds that carbon emissions standards proposed by the Environmental Protection Agency in 2015 for coal-fired power plants in United State will substantially improve human health and prevent thousands of premature deaths each year.

byline.original: By SABRINA TAVERNISE and CORAL DAVENPORT

lead_paragraph: The carbon emissions standards, proposed last year for the nation’s coal-fired power plants, could prevent more than 3,000 premature deaths per year, according to a new study.

headline.main: E.P.A. Carbon Emissions Plan Could Save Thousands of Lives, Study Finds
headline.print_headline: E.P.A. Carbon Emissions Proposal Could Save Thousands of Lives, Study Suggests
